Award.AwardTitle: Might Young Makers Be The Engineers Of The Future?

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this study is to understand Young Makers in K-12 and how their knowledge,
skills, and attitudes might prepare them to pursue advanced STEM education and careers. This
study will advance the currently limited knowledge of the Young Maker community by
developing theory characterizing Young Makers and their pathways through the lens of formal
engineering education. The aim is to establish evidence as to how Making benefits Young
Makers and affects their pathways to STEM majors and related careers.

The results of this study will transform the conversation of who Young Makers could become,
linking Making with engineering in the same way that students who excel in science and math
are pointed toward engineering by parents and career counselors. By sharing a diverse (by age,
gender, and ethnicity) set of success profiles of Young Makers widely in the formal education
system to students, K-12 school administrators, university leaders, admissions officers, and to
Young Makers both online and at Young Maker community events, we aim to illuminate
pathways for Young Makers to become the engineers of the future. In addition, this study could
inform future innovation in formal K-12 STEM pedagogy based on successful attributes of
informal engineering education and tinkering activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
“making” community builds additive innovations

Might Young Makers Be the Engineers of the Future?

Shawn Jordan (PI)/Micah Lande, Arizona State University (NSF EEC 1329321)

outcomes

Young Makers are part of a community of builders and tinkerers that celebrate and share their creations through events like Maker Faires. Through interviews with 4 dozen Young Makers Makers (and 3 dozen of their parents) at flagship Maker Faires in the US, our research team has captured maker educational pathways, and the knowledge, skills, and attitudes developed during their Making activities and might prepare them to pursue advanced STEM education and careers. The results of this study can transform the conversation of who Young Makers could become, linking Making with engineering in the same way that students who excel in science and math are pointed toward engineering by parents and career counselors.

 

impact / benefits of research

Results suggest the following understanding of the Maker community:

What Making Means. Participants collectively defined “making” as “making something.” It matters less what the creation is but more so the act of creating and building an artifact.

Additive Innovation. Participants actively practice additive innovation, where they contribute to an open community of sharing and learning. Citizenship in the Maker community means additively building on the work of others and freely sharing knowledge and processes back with the community. The Making community is an additive innovation network, both as a social and intellectual community.

Making in Informal Spaces. Making encourages students to be creative lifelong learners, and can be beneficial to both formal and informal modes of STEM education. In making-based museum environments, parents were found to take multiple roles of builders, designers, facilitators, teachers, environment formers, and cheerleaders when supporting their children.

Making contrasted with formal learning. Young makers contrasted their Making with their experience in school with science fairs. Participating in Maker Faires, study participants believe, provides more applied learning about science, engineering, and community concepts as compared to their participation in science fairs.

Self-Direction and Knowledge acquisition. Young Makers draw inspiration from their interests and make within their existing personal context. They seek out formal and informal mentors that can be experts or near-peers and peer with a little bit more knowledge. Young Makers learn a variety of skills and knowledge to create technically sophisticated artifacts of personal interest in their informal making activities. Makers learn how to communicate technical details to a wider audience, some learning valuable techniques to foster lifelong learning, some learning how to apply engineering knowledge to solve problems, and some learning specific skills applicable to electrical engineering and manufacturing engineering programs in college.

Lifelong learning and developing expertise. Prototyping and building provides a specific means to acquire adaptive design expertise. A disposition to apply skills to develop work prototypes can provide a breadth of experience. By attending the Maker Faire, where they can exhibit anything from a functional prototype to a start-up’s minimum viable product, Makers are able to receive feedback from the Maker Community, and expand their learning ecology or learn from others’ past experience.

Identity formation as Makers, as STEM thinkers. Further examination of Young Maker identity could provide insights into the psychosocial process of “becoming” a Maker as well as a tool for helping educational institutions refocus their efforts on creating opportunities for students to develop their Maker identities through Relational-identity and Preferential-identity prior to Material Discourse-identity and Affinity-identity. The young adults we interviewed suggested that connections with supportive friends and family, deep engagement with tools and materials, and chances to pursue one’s interests are key ingredients for developing authentic Makers.

Bridging to First-year Engineering students. Our work investigates what engineering students learn from their educational pathways and engagement with making about (awareness) and during (context) the beginning of their engineering studies. Makers are gaining experience in a variety of ABET a-k (Student Outcomes) applicable experiences. Over three-quarters are learning effective communication skills (g), over half display traits associated with successful lifelong learning (i), and a third are identifying and solving engineering problems through system design with realistic constraints (a, c, e).

Implications for Designing Making-Based Learning Experiences. There is an opportunity to connect engineering Making and doing to undergraduate engineering curricula by considering how aspects of Making (Sharing, Practical ingenuity, Personal investment, Playful invention, Risk taking, Community building, and Self-directed learning) could apply in the undergraduate classroom. Making-Based Learning can support students in academic Makerspaces. It is also a potential magnet for attracting and recruiting a broader base of engineering students. An inversion of the values of engineering analysis and engineering doing may be necessary to fully and authentically support the role of Making in the classroom. At the very least, it is possible to imagine engineering curricular reform and support for active and project-based learning wrapped up in Making-Based Learning.
